name: Húsavík
description: Húsavík is a charming coastal town of approximately 2,300 residents in North Iceland, universally recognized as the "Whale Watching Capital of the World" and "Whale Watching Capital of Europe" due to exceptional marine mammal viewing opportunities in Skjálfandi Bay. Located on the eastern shore of Skjálfandi Bay approximately 90 kilometers northeast of Akureyri, the town's nutrient-rich waters attract up to 23 different whale species including humpback whales, minke whales, harbor porpoises, white-beaked dolphins, and occasionally the magnificent blue whale—Earth's largest animal. Additionally, large colonies of Atlantic puffins nest on islands within the bay during summer months from May through August, offering combined whale and puffin viewing excursions. Multiple whale watching companies operate from Húsavík harbor, with Gentle Giants Whale Watching earning TripAdvisor awards for 14 consecutive years through 2025, testament to consistently high-quality experiences. Success rates for whale sightings between June and August in Skjálfandi Bay approach near-certainty, with some operators offering free return trips if no whales are spotted. Tours typically last 2.5 to 3 hours departing from the picturesque harbor, using traditional oak boats or modern RIBs (rigid inflatable boats) for closer encounters. The town gained international pop culture recognition from the 2020 Netflix film Eurovision Song Contest: The Story of Fire Saga starring Will Ferrell and Rachel McAdams, which prominently featured Húsavík and the beloved song "Húsavík (My Hometown)" that earned an Academy Award nomination for Best Original Song. The film sparked renewed tourist interest in this already popular destination. GeoSea Geothermal Sea Baths, perched on a cliff overlooking Skjálfandi Bay, provides a unique bathing experience using seawater geothermally heated to comfortable temperatures and rich in minerals beneficial for skin health. Unlike most Icelandic hot springs fed by freshwater, GeoSea's infinity pools use filtered, heated seawater offering stunning ocean views while soaking in 38-39°C water. The facility includes indoor and outdoor pools, hot tubs, saunas, and a restaurant serving Icelandic cuisine. Many whale watching operators offer discounted GeoSea entrance (typically 15% off) with tour tickets, creating a perfect day combining wildlife viewing with relaxing bathing. The town's cultural attractions include the Húsavík Whale Museum displaying 11 whale skeletons and comprehensive cetacean biology exhibits, the distinctive Húsavíkurkirkja wooden church built in 1907 in Swiss chalet style with its recognizable red roof, and the Exploration Museum documenting human exploration from Viking voyages through the Apollo moon missions. Húsavík provides comprehensive visitor services including Fosshotel Húsavík (North Iceland's largest conference hotel after 2016 expansion), Húsavík Cape Hotel, numerous guesthouses, restaurants and cafés including the microbrewery Ölstofan serving locally-brewed beers, a geothermal swimming pool with hot tubs and water slide, campsites, a golf course, and a small ski area. The harbor area features colorful buildings, fishing boats, and tour vessels creating a quintessentially Icelandic coastal atmosphere.
